messageBody:
peter_r_guinness scripsit:

> There is something that I would be glad to have your opinion on. I'm
> not sure which is the best letter to use for the General American
> spelling of the sound /o/. Such as in FORCE set word alternatives
> like _more_ -> /mor/ -> May+?+Roe. (Under the proposal the IntQS
> spelling is May+Awe+Roe but I don't know what the GA spelling should
> be). I don't have this sound as a pure vowel in my Australian accent
> so am not very familiar with it but from what understand it is the
> first phone of the way I pronouce the diphthong Owe /oU/. Would Owe be
> the best choice of QS letter?

The first thing to get clear is that "General American" is a purely
notional accent: very few people in the United States use it, with the
exception of trained actors and the like. Until about fifty years ago,
if you ignored the accents of the East Coast cities, the South (the
old Confederacy), and Eastern New England, you got a fairly uniform
accent across the rest of the country with only minor local variations.
This got tagged "General American".

This uniformity is no longer present: a variety of vowel shifts, splits,
and mergers operating in different parts of the U.S. has divided the old
"General American" accent into a variety of new accents. Dictionaries,
however, have not caught up with any of these changes, and now promote
an accent that can best be understood as taking the U.S. accents (still
excluding the Eastern cities, the South, and Eastern New England) and
removing all local pronunciation features.

For example, most of the speakers in this area (as well as the whole
of Canada except the extreme eastern provinces) now merge Awe and Ah
(THOUGHT=PALM) except before "r", where START and NORTH=FORCE are still
distinct. This merger apparently began in the West and has been spreading
eastward steadily; older speakers in the eastern part of the old GA area
do not have it. However, dictionaries still consistently distinguish
THOUGHT and PALM, though whether NORTH and FORCE are distinguished
depends on the dictionary.

The answer to your specific question is that Awe+Roe is appropriate for
both NORTH and FORCE words in GA. We use the /oU/ diphthong for GOAT,
as used to be the case in RP until the beginning of the 20th century,
and is still the case in Ireland.
